fields.description:
This feature request was issued (and implemented) against Bitbucket Server, but as noted there it requires another issue here for Bitbucket Cloud.

Git v2.5.0 introduced uploadpack.allowReachableSHA1InWant, which allows fetching any commit from a remote repository as long as that commit is reachable from at least one ref. This can be useful for grabbing smaller subsets of large repositories at specific commits.

Since allowReachableSHA1InWant only allows access to commits reachable from at least one ref, it's not exposing any commits to which a remote client would not already have access; it just means they can fetch such commits directly, rather than having to fetch a ref (which may include a significant amount of unnecessary data in the resulting pack) and then checkout the desired commit.

This option will be specially useful to us to speed up the build in Bitbucket Pipelines.
fields.summary: Enable uploadpack.allowReachableSHA1InWant

fields.description:
When reviewing pull requests and browsing commits it would be really cool to be able to open a particular file at a particular line in your IDE for further browsing. Bitbucket could support this by supporting protocol handlers that IDEs could register with the browser/OS.

Lets say we use the url scheme sourcelocation, then it could be something like this:

sourcelocation://?gitrepo=git@bitbucket.org:foo/bar.git&commit_id=57ceda89a380a0e43a91f0df3561b9437647a307&filename=src/Foo.cc&line=42

The protocol handler link should be easy to access by clicking somewhere on the line, e.g in the left side in a manner similar to how you add a comment.
fields.summary: IDE Integration via protocol handler

fields.description:
I have a Pipeline with a couple of caches (node, bower) and a Docker service container. Sometimes the "Build setup" step fails to complete silently:

* umask 000
* git clone --branch="master" --depth 50 ...\\
Cloning into '/opt/atlassian/pipelines/agent/build'...\\
HEAD is now at ...
* chmod 777 $BUILD_DIR\\
Cache "node": Downloading\\
Cache "node": Extracting\\
<no more output>

If I rerun it, it usually works.

* umask 000
* git clone --branch="master" --depth 50 ...\\
Cloning into '/opt/atlassian/pipelines/agent/build'...\\
HEAD is now at ...
* chmod 777 $BUILD_DIR\\
Cache "node": Downloading\\
Cache "node": Extracting\\
Cache "node": Extracted\\
Cache "bower": Downloading\\
Cache "bower": Extracting\\
Cache "bower": Extracted

I suspect that there is some internal ~2 minute timeout on the "Build setup" step...when it works, it usually takes about 1.5 minutes (which is really slow compared to the 1.5 seconds it takes on my laptop if everything is already cached, but these are known issues). I suppose there are a few separate issues:

# How do I debug "Build setup" failures?
# Is there a timeout for this step? Can it be increased?
# Are there any logs for the service container? If the service container fails to deploy, how would I know?
fields.summary: Build setup fails silently

fields.description:
Add support for adding directories to search for Test Report XML files in the bitbucket-pipelines.yml. For example:

{code}
#!
pipelines:
  default:
    - step:
        test-reports:
          - ~/a/very/far/far/far/away/file/from/the/normal/scanner/*.xml
          - ~/**/different-name-to-default
        script:
          - echo "Hello"
{code}

As a follow up on [Track Tests in Pipelines - Unit Tests|BCLOUD-12738].

For customers interested in this issue, can you please include your use-case for configuring this explicitly in the YAML. We're also curious if the build tool you are using supports reconfiguring the output directory of the test report generator.
fields.summary: Configure Searched Test Report Directories in the YAML

fields.description:
Hola All,

Currently we are using build for both testing and production workflows. In both cases, there are manual steps that must be completed before the build is "complete". However, there is no easy way of picking which build needs these steps completed.

This is tricky particularly with testing stuff, in which the build completes to bring up an environment, but pauses on a "manual trigger" before tearing it down again. Without being able to see quickly whether builds have been completed 100% (rather than just successful to the point of the manual trigger), it's difficult to get an easy overview of the builds that haven't eben torn down yet.

Some indicator (changing the symbol here from green to blue if it's got steps remaining, or having a yellow "!' indicator indicating "action required") would be my good
fields.summary: Indicate that a build has remaining manual steps

I locally interrupted an 'hg push' to our private repository, and now when I try to push again it returns the following:

{code}
#!bash

pushing to ssh://hg@bitbucket.org/twigtek/aya
searching for changes
remote: abort: abandoned transaction found!
remote: (run 'hg recover' to clean up transaction)
abort: stream ended unexpectedly (got 0 bytes, expected 4)
{code}

'hg verify' returns no errors, locally.

According to a various online forums (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/14218390/how-to-resolve-abandoned-transaction-when-i-use-hg-push for example), 'hg recover' needs to be run on the server.

Our repository is at: https://bitbucket.org/twigtek/aya

Please advise; thanks,

Gideon

fields.description:
Hello, guys.

There are three state of a build: {{FAILED}}, {{INPROGRESS}}, {{SUCCESSFUL}}.

I believe this is not sufficient when some CI system _is aware_ of the pull request, but haven't started building it. Thus the {{PENDING}} state would be appropriate.

The point is we can't report {{INPROGRESS}} when the build isn't in fact in progress, yet not reporting anything is also not perfect because we don't know whether our CI is working.
fields.summary: PENDING - new state of a build

fields.summary: project "issues" page should indicate users need to log in

fields.description:
We use Git Flow for our branching strategy (http://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model) That basically our branches represent different levels of stability:

* master branch is the most stable.
* release-x.y.z is not as stable as master, but more stable than,
* develop branch which is again more stable than
* feature-my-awesome-feature branch.

Having merge checks makes perfect sense when merging from lesser stable to more stable branches, such as merging a feature branch into develop (there the merge checks and pull requests are a way to increase stability).

However, merging the other way is always considered safe, i.e., it is always safe to merge release-x.y.z branch into develop, since that should not decrease stability of the develop branch since the release branch is more stable.

With the current implementation of merge checks it is only possible to restrict on the target branch. For example, it means I can only implement rules for the develop branch and those rules are the same if it is a feature branch or a release-x.y.z branches that should be merged.

I would like to have a method for the developers to easily do the safe merges from stable branches to the lesser stable branches without having to go through pull requests and all of the merge checks.

Link to the relevant repository: https://bitbucket.org/mirrobots/mir
fields.summary: Safe merges from certain branches without merge checks

fields.description: After our migration to Aa, we no longer have the ability to remove old session data in Bitbucket. Would be nice to give customers the option to do this as well.
fields.summary: Give customers ability to kill sessions / erase session data

fields.description:
Exactly what I did:

{code}
git reset --hard master
git push -f
{code}

In a branch that had an open pull request to master.

The pull request showed up in the merged pull requests, which was quite scary because it failed tests before the reset. The diff showed as the diff of the previous commit, but the commits section said "There are no changes".

I would not think it is intended behavior. Resets like this are usually for starting over, and there is usually still discussion going on in the PR.
fields.summary: When pushing forcefully after a reset to a branch with an open PR, it shows as merged

fields.description: !1527323650-error.png|thumbnail!

Also, we don't have branch commit history for master or staging at the least in the UI.

please advise.

fields.description:
h2. Steps to reproduce
# Link a Jira instance to Bitbucket Cloud
# Create a branch from an issue with the issue key as the name
# Create a commit in the new branch
# Create a pull request from the new branch

h3. Expected Output
The Pull Request should be linked to the Jira issue through its branch name

bq. Ensure that the source branch name includes the issue key.


https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirasoftwarecloud/referencing-issues-in-your-development-work-777002789.html

h3. Actual Output
The Pull Request is not linked to the Jira issue.

h2. Workaround
Link the Jira issue by adding the issue key in the PR description.
fields.summary: Pull Request is not linked to Jira Issue through branch name

fields.description:
h2. Summary
CodeDeploy addon was removed due to an unkown cause without any logs.

h2. Environment
* Bitbucket Cloud with [AWS CodeDeploy for Bitbucket|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/bitbucket-aws-codedeploy/cloud/overview]

h2. Steps to Reproduce
N/A

h2. Expected Results
CodeDeploy addon should not be uninstalled without proper reason. At least Bitbucket Cloud should output logs for investigation when addon removed.

h2. Actual Results
CodeDeploy addon is suddenly removed without any logs. Therefore the further investigation was unavailable.

h2. Notes
There were no logs which indicate that user intentionally uninstalled.

h2. Workaround
None.
fields.summary: CodeDeploy addon has gone due to unknown cause

fields.description:
I'm fairly new to the Atlassian suite. Great to be aboard :)

We create feature branches, create PR's afterwards to do a Code review with. Something I miss in the whole interface is seeing my activity in an overview on repositories and branches made in repositories (not under profile, because that shows all commits also, making me feel like i'm losing overview)

I've been working in many different branches and creating PR's for those after my work was complete. I felt like losing oversight in the whole PR process because there is not really (to my knowledge) overview where I can check against the branches i worked in vs seeing what PR's I've already made.

I also think I've found a flaw in the interface. I'm still able to find the branch I've created a PR for when creating it and telling it to close the branch after merge (and code review). It seems a little illogical to me to keep that branch in the "Create PR" view when there is already a PR created for a branch that will be closed after the PR.

That's just my 2 cents :)
fields.summary: Overview Pull Request -> Code Review

fields.description:
"Check the last commit for "x" successful build and *no failed builds*"

This merge check should prevent the merge of a pull request when there still some builds running because it means that the last build(s) status may not be a "success".

How to Replicate

# Run multiple builds on the same commit
# Open a pull request after the *first one* run with success and the second and/or third *still running*.
# Press "merge" to merge the pull request (you will not be prompted to wait for the build(s) to run).
fields.summary: Merge Checks are not working properly (BBS-68567)

fields.description:
The initial (alpha) release of Deployments only offered three fixed environments: test, staging, production.

However difference projects often have more and refer to them with different names.

For example:

* Development
* System Test
* System Integration Test
* User Acceptance Test
* Training
* Production

Having a fixed number (and named) set of deployment environments makes this otherwise desirable feature unusable since they are not going to invest in one technology to deploy to 3 environments and another for the remaining environments.
fields.summary: Enhance Deployments to support flexible environments

Hello,

I recently tried a Jira/Confluence/BitBucket Cloud trial for my company and I could not figure out how to add that 3 lines button present in jira and confluence to switch between apps to my Bitbucket app. I linked the bitbucket to my jira and agreed to every permissions asked. Still no button at the bottom left. Seems like Jira knows about Bitbucket, but bitbucket doesnt.

That bugs me a lot even tho its a dumb problem.

P.S. Why isnt there an icon of every apps I subscribed to in the left navigation bar with the loop and the "+" sign, that looks to me like a place screaming for more Icons...

Thank you.
fields.summary: 3 lined button bottom left not showing up

fields.description:
We are using all the latest tools from Bitbucket and our organization is growing very fast, we have around 300 developers aprox. and I am starting to worry about giving new developers write access to their own repo because that also means anyone could run the pipelines manually and that also means have access to make installations into production. The request could be to restrict permission to specific accounts or users who can execute pipelines including the "schedule" pipeline.

Or to configure the pipeline file within the project settings, so nobody knows what configurations are fully set
fields.summary: Restrict pipeline execution by single users

fields.description:
I'm using Jenkins as CI. Every build it get the content of Jenkinsfile (similar to .travis.yml file) from the branch to be build.

We are also using git flow so all our branches are named feature/123 release/1.0 etc etc.\\
With the old version 1.0 of REST API works like a sharm\\
https://api.bitbucket.org/1.0/repositories/acme/myrepo/src/feature%2F31435/Jenkinsfile

but the Jenkins plugin for bitbucket has migrate to the newer version 2.0 and it fails with a 404\\
https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/acme/myrepo/src/feature%2F31435/Jenkinsfile

I had also try without encoding the slash in the branch name, I got same issue\\
https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/acme/myrepo/src/feature/31435/Jenkinsfile
fields.summary: REST API 2.0 to get raw content of an individual file on fails in case of slash in the branch name.

fields.description:
If there is code in your repository you can see this nice select box that allows you see both the https and ssh link for your repository.

!925558016-Screenshot_20171212_123015.png|thumbnail!

If your repository is empty this select box is missing, but you can find the link to the repository below, here:

!403825445-Screenshot_20171212_123604.png|thumbnail!

The problem with this however is that you cannot choose to view the https link of the repository if you wish to use it instead of ssh. The site assumes that because I have ssh keys added to my account I want to always use ssh, but this is not the case.

There are currently two workarounds I know of to get around this issue:

# Remove all ssh from your account. It will display the https link instead.
# Add a file to the repository using the site, which gives back your handy select box.

On a side note I vaguely remember this select box being there in the old Bitbucket layout. I would like to get it back.
fields.summary: Cannot see https link on empty repository if a ssh key has been added to your account.

fields.description:
It has been observed that while comparing two branches on bitbucket, it comes up with a message "This merge is too large to display".

After refreshing multiple times, it shows the actual difference. The actual difference between two branches is very small, mostly changes in one to four files which is very less difference and can be shown.
fields.summary: This merge is too large to display

fields.description:
I have a repo that runs fine through pipelines with the following structure:

{code}
#!yml

image: phpunit/phpunit:5.0.3
pipelines:
    branches:
        master: # Master is the release branch. Releases automatically propogate when tagged with a version number.
            - step: &testphp
                script: # CI unit test step.
                  - apt-get update && apt-get install -y unzip
                  - curl -sS https://getcomposer.org/installer | php -- --install-dir=/usr/local/bin --filename=composer
                  - composer install
                  - phpunit -c phpunit.xml
        dev: # Tests must pass on dev before going to release on master.
            - step: *testphp
{code}

This has been running without issue for quite some time. I recently forked the repo to give it a dedicated repository for public releases, and Pipelines is telling me that the syntax is not valid because dev does not have the required script key. It absolutely does, and the engine that runs pipelines has no issue discovering it through the yml alias.

However, whatever is authenticating the bitbucket-pipelines.yml before it has run at all is not parsing the yml correctly, and is apparently incapable of determining correct aliasing. This seems to only occur on a new repo that has not run pipelines at all yet, but detects a pipelines file.

This has caused problems getting my branches out of sync between the development master branch and the release master branch, because the site will not allow the repo to have ssh keys set without pipelines being configured when a pipelines file is present.

*Relevant Uri Path:*

_(only fires on an initial visit for a new repo that already has a pipelines file as outlined above)_\\
https://bitbucket.org/projectname/reponame/addon/pipelines/home#!/getting-started

*Repo where issue was noticed:*

https://bitbucket.org/oroborosframework/oroboros-core-releases

*Steps to reproduce:*

* Clone an existing repo locally
* Edit the bitbucket-pipelines.yml as shown above, so the *step* key is aliased between two branches.
* Push the repo to a new empty repository on Bitbucket Cloud
* Visit the Pipelines tab. You will see the apparent (misconfigured) error message.

!780776615-by%20default%202017-12-11%20at%2011.14.00%20PM.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Pipelines YAML validator fails with aliases, breaks enabling Pipelines on new repo

fields.description:

This can result in jitter in the UI and also browser issues.

This ticket was created to capture reports of this behaviour.
fields.summary: Auto scroll in Pipelines is not performant.

fields.summary: Connection interrupted. Retrying... After board loads.

fields.description:
Hi!

Please look at the time consumed on the attached image and compare it to the total time printed in the logs. I pay for 39 seconds of running the process but only ~3 seconds of the run are explained. Of course I am aware of the fact that there is starting agent and pulling image running underneath. I just would like to know how long each part takes. And also I would like to know if the Docker image is pulled or the cache is used.

According to https://blog.bitbucket.org/2017/08/22/bringing-speed-power-flexibility-12-new-features-bitbucket-pipelines/ there is new feature - "Public image caching – Behind the scenes, Pipelines has recently started caching public Docker images, resulting in a noticeable boost to startup time to all builds running on our infrastructure." and I would like to see if the cache is used or not.
fields.summary: List all consumed time

fields.description:
At the top of the grid where your tickets are located, (i.e. "title", "T", "P") the onhover highlights the whole tab but if you want to actually sort by that tab you have to click on the word itself instead of being able to click in the highlighted area.

It sounds like a little thing but we've had discussions about if the sorting is broken or not because the uninitiated don't click on the actual word. (Also, it can sometimes be hard to hit the single letter links when you are in a hurry)
fields.summary: Sort tabs only work if you click on words, not highlighted area around them

fields.description:
A user on my team properly committed a file that is tracked/trackable by LFS.\\
He then pushed the change to his origin. The LFS file appears there as expected,\\
in LFS file storage.

The user then issued a pull request to our upstream repo. The PR was approved and merged. However, the LFS file was not transferred to upstream. The merged commit, when viewed from upstream has an entry for that file, but the preview says "LFS file missing."

Bitbucket does clearly say [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/current-limitations-for-git-lfs-with-bitbucket-828781638.html] that you must manually take care of LFS files while forking, but the mention of pull requests is much more subtle, which is surprising since the pull request use case is so much more common.

In any case, if it can't handle pull requests, the LFS feature is broken. Pull requests (and forking, for that matter) are important parts of the git development process, and leaving a repository corrupted (the repository cannot be pulled properly until the files are properly in LFS storage) is a serious bug. Until it is fixed I am discouraging frequent LFS use.
fields.summary: LFS files not properly transferred across repos when merging pull requests

fields.description:
We are using pipelines alpha.

Because pipelines now supports ECR it is using the AWS api to download ECR images into North Virginia from my ECR region.

This causes an inter-region data transfer which costs 14c per GB. Last month this cost over $100 USD just to run our many pipelines last month.

This would be less of an issue if the docker images were cached, which would also speed up the pipelines setup.

Alternatively, we should know which regions pipelines runs in (i suspect only North Virginia) so we can move our ECR images into so prevent this data transfer.
fields.summary: Pipelines causes large download costs when using ECR

fields.description:
The "Limitations of Bitbucket Pipelines" documentation states that the disk space is limited to 5GB. This is not enough for our use case (deployment to GCS) and I'd like to see this as a parameter in build configuration. Another option would be to dynamically adjust the space available to the project size (+ a few GB headroom).

Git LFS support in Pipelines is also deeply linked to this issue but we can get away with that limitation by using a custom docker image.
fields.summary: Configurable disk space for builds

fields.description:
Hi,

An app vendor's experiencing issue with the {{https://bitbucket.org/site/oauth2/access_token}} endpoint on their app. After calling the endpoint with the password appended with %00 (NUL character), doing any git pull or fetch, then user is presented with credentials error

Steps to reproduce:

# A standard rest call (can be done in postman or cURL):

{code}
POST https://bitbucket.org/site/oauth2/access_token
Header:
Authorization : Basic {base64 of client_id and password}

Body:
Set as : x-www-form-urlencoded


grant_type=password
username=<urlencoded_username>
password=<urlencoded_password>%00
{code}

The appended %00 is a NUL character and would look like an empty character. It is caused by a buggy base64 encoding scheme and issue was discovered via that.

# Running the command seems to succeed for OAuth, however the user who authenticated is no longer able to successfully authenticate for push or pull operations on their bitbucket repository using https authentication
# Logging in the Bitbucket website resolves this issue

For more information, please see [DEVHELP-828|https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/DEVHELP-828]

Cheers,\\
Anne Calantog
fields.summary: Bitbucket oauth2 authentication breaks git authentication (appended %00 in the password parameter) (BBCDEV-8923)

fields.description: A branch shows a list of contributors, it would be very nice to find a branch by contributor, especially like "show branches where I have committed something".
fields.summary: Filter branches by contributors, especially current user

I want to set up the different reviewer groups using the branch pattern or branch name. This is the link I am following - [https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/add-default-reviewers-to-pull-requests-834221295.html]. I do not see the add default reviewers dialogue window available on my current repositories. I have reached out to the support and here is what they responded with....

This is what Atlassian support relayed to me "The documentation that you're referring is for our Bitbucket Server(Self-hosted) product instead of Bitbucket Cloud(bitbucket.org). Nonetheless, if you wish to have this feature implemented in Bitbucket Cloud, you can submit a feature request here: [https://bitbucket.org/site/master/issues]"
fields.summary: Set default reviewers based on branch pattern/branch name

fields.description:
As a follow on the ability to [parse test from a pipeline|BCLOUD-12738], it would be great to be able to track individual test case history.  This means seeing a history on a per-test basis, the way Bamboo Cloud used to do it (with, I'm sure, a much simpler UI).  This allowed s to quickly look for tests that failed sporadically, how often they failed, etc.  History for all time is not necessarily required -- just some reasonable amount of history -- say the last 50 or 100 pipelines or something like that.

(The Quarantine feature was nice too (which meant pass the build anyhow - but that requires more knowledge of the build process/tooling itself), but I suspect that would be difficult to do in pipelines and is not strictly necessary.)
fields.summary: Track Test History in Pipelines
